<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Interest income on tax-advantaged
    investment securities reflects a tax-equivalent adjustment based
    on a marginal federal corporate tax rate of 35%. The total tax
    equivalent adjustment reflected in the above table is
    approximately $4.3&#160;million, $4.6&#160;million, and
    $4.5&#160;million, for the years ended 2007, 2006, and 2005,
    respectively.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Provision for
    Loan Losses</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We provide for an adequate allowance for loan losses that are
    probable and reasonably estimable in the portfolio. The
    provision for loan losses reflects management&#146;s latest
    assessment of the inherent losses in the loan portfolio. Our
    allowance for probable loan losses is reassessed monthly to
    determine the appropriate level of the reserve. Our analysis is
    influenced by the following factors: assessment of the credit
    risk of the loans in the portfolio, delinquent loans, impaired
    loans, evaluation of current economic conditions in the market
    area, actual charge-offs and recoveries during the period,
    industry loss averages and historical loss experience. A
    discussion of the allowance for loan losses and the factors on
    which provisions are based begins on page&#160;50.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Credit quality deterioration during the year, among other
    factors, resulted in a provision for loan losses of
    $16.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007, up
    from $6.8&#160;million for 2006 and $6.5&#160;million for 2005.
    Net charge-offs for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007 were
    $6.1&#160;million compared to charge-offs of $873,000 for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006 and net recoveries of $250,000
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    40
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

</TD>

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest income increased by $3.1&#160;million, or 13%, to
    $26.3&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007
    compared to $23.2&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 and $19.0&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005. The increase in non-interest income
    during 2007 was primarily due to an increase in The
    PrivateWealth Group fee revenue and also due to an increase in
    mortgage banking income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The PrivateWealth&#160;Group fee revenue was $16.2&#160;million
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007, an increase from
    $13.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 and
    $9.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005. The
    year over year increase in The PrivateWealth&#160;Group fee
    revenue was primarily due to the growth in net new business, and
    increase in the value of accounts due to an increase in market
    value and the change of fee structures for certain client
    relationships. The PrivateWealth&#160;Group assets under
    management increased 16% to $3.4&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2007 compared to $2.9&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and $2.4&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Mortgage banking income for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2007 increased to $4.5&#160;million compared to
    $3.3&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 and
    $3.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005.
    Mortgage banking income increased over these periods due to a
    higher volume of loans sold.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Banking and other services income decreased 24% to
    $3.6&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007
    compared to $4.7&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006. The decrease from the prior year period
    is primarily due to the inclusion of a $1.4&#160;million gain
    associated with the sale of FHLB (Chicago) advances during the
    second quarter 2006 as a result of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Chicago&#146;s withdrawal of our membership at that time.
    Banking and other services income for 2007 includes $646,000 of
    insurance proceeds the Company received during the second
    quarter 2007 covering a portion of losses the company incurred
    in the fourth quarter 2006 as a result of a previously disclosed
    employee fraud. Banking and other services income increased for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 by $1.8&#160;million over
    2005, due to growth in the Company during 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest income in 2007 includes net investment securities
    gains of $348,000 compared to net losses of $310,000 in the
    prior year period, and net gains of $903,000 for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005. The Company retired its interest rate
    swap in the third quarter 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2007, 2006, and 2005 we recognized income of
    $1.7&#160;million $1.6&#160;million, and $1.4&#160;million,
    respectively, related to the increased cash surrender value of
    bank owned life insurance (BOLI) policies. Income recognized on
    this product increased in 2006 as compared to 2005 primarily due
    to increases in the underlying policy yields. These policies
    cover certain higher-level employees who are deemed to be
    significant contributors to the Company. All employees included
    in this policy are aware and have consented to the coverage. The
    cash surrender value of BOLI at December&#160;31, 2007 was
    $44.2&#160;million,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    41
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    compared to $42.5&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006 and
    $40.9&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005, and is included in
    other assets on the balance sheet.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest expense increased $43.3&#160;million, or 55%, to
    $122.4&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007
    compared to $79.1&#160;million for the prior year period
    primarily due to increased compensation-related expenses,
    professional fees and occupancy costs incurred during the year,
    and specifically in the fourth quarter 2007, due to the
    implementation of our Strategic Growth Plan and overall growth
    of the Company during 2007. The increase in non-interest expense
    from prior year also reflects a full year of expenses from The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, compared to the prior year
    period. Costs incurred associated with the Plan include
    $13.7&#160;million in sign-on bonus payments to new hires and
    $2.5&#160;million of professional and legal fees associated with
    the recruitment and hiring of new employees. Additionally, we
    made transformation equity awards to new employees and certain
    foundation employees. The transformation equity awards had a
    total GAAP value of approximately $48.0&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2007. The cost of these Transformation Equity
    Awards will be expensed over the five-year period ending
    December&#160;31, 2012. Amortization costs associated with these
    awards totaled $2.0&#160;million for the fourth quarter 2007.
    Also included in non-interest expenses for the year were
    approximately $2.0&#160;million in regular salary expenses
    related to new hires pursuant to the Plan. Professional fees
    increased 74% year over year due to legal and consulting fees
    incurred related to the general growth of the Company and costs
    associated with implementing our Strategic Growth Plan,
    including the recruitment of new hires. Occupancy costs also
    increased 35% year over year as the Company acquired additional
    office space at existing locations and expanded into new
    geographic markets. While growth rates of salary and occupancy
    expenses will remain at higher levels during the first half of
    2008, we expect the growth rate of non-interest expenses to
    normalize during the second half of 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest expense increased $16.3&#160;million, or 26%, to
    $79.1&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006
    compared to $62.7&#160;million for 2005. The growth in
    non-interest expense during 2006 was a result of increases in
    personnel-related expense, occupancy expense, professional fees,
    and wealth management fees. The increase in non-interest expense
    from the prior year reflects a full year of expenses from
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan and
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin, compared to the
    prior year period. The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan
    incurred non-interest expense of $9.0&#160;million and
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin incurred non-interest
    expense of $2.5&#160;million during 2006. Some additional
    expenses incurred during 2006 include approximately $615,000 of
    expenses recognized in conjunction with the move of our
    corporate headquarters into larger offices during the third
    quarter 2006, and $1.2&#160;million in expenses attributable to
    the fraud loss discovered during the fourth quarter 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    42
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The periods presented include stock option expense of
    $4.9&#160;million in 2007, $2.0&#160;million in 2006, and
    $2.8&#160;million in 2005. Effective January&#160;1, 2006, the
    Company adopted the fair value recognition provisions of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R), &#147;Accounting for
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Stock-Based</FONT>
    Compensation.&#148; The Company elected the
    modified-retrospective-transition method, which results in the
    restatement of prior periods by recognizing compensation cost in
    the amounts previously reported in the pro forma financial
    statement footnote disclosures. Compensation cost recognized
    includes the cost of all share-based payments granted, but not
    yet fully vested in all periods presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to January&#160;1, 2006, the Company accounted for its
    stock-based employee compensation plans under the recognition
    and measurement provisions of APB&#160;Opinion No.&#160;25,
    &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; and
    related Interpretations, as permitted by
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R), &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
    Compensation.&#148; No stock-based employee compensation was
    recognized in the Consolidated Statements of Income in periods
    prior to the restatements under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R), as
    all options granted under the Company&#146;s compensation plans
    had an exercise price equal to the market value of the
    underlying common stock on the date of grant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the adoption of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R), the Company
    presented all tax benefits of deductions resulting from the
    exercise of stock options and vesting of restricted shares as
    operating cash flows in the Statement of Cash Flows.
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R) requires the cash flows resulting from
    the tax benefits of these tax deductions in excess of the
    compensation cost recognized for those share-based payments (the
    excess tax benefits) be classified as financing cash flows. The
    excess tax benefit in financing cash flows was $1.4&#160;million
    in 2006 and $1.2&#160;million in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Salary and employee benefits expense increased 62% to
    $71.2&#160;million in 2007, compared to $43.9&#160;million in
    2006. The increase is a result of the implementation of our
    Strategic Growth Plan during the fourth quarter 2007 and the
    associated hiring of a new Chief Executive Officer, several
    executive-level managing directors and many
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">line-of-business</FONT>
    managing directors. Full-time equivalent (FTE) employees
    increased 27% to 597 FTEs at December&#160;31, 2007, compared to
    471 FTEs at December&#160;31, 2006. This includes the addition
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    promotion of 76 managing directors and associate managing
    directors during 2007 to 224 at the end of 2007, compared to 148
    at the end of 2006. A substantial part of the 2007 growth
    occurred during the fourth quarter when the Company hired a net
    total of 56 new managing directors. The increase in salary and
    employee benefits expense in 2007 also includes a full year of
    expenses for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Salary and employee benefit expense increased 21% to
    $43.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006
    from $36.3&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2005. During 2006, we added 85 FTEs, an increase of 22%, to
    approximately 471 FTEs from 386 FTEs at December&#160;31, 2005.
    The increase in salary and benefit expense in 2006 also includes
    a full year of expenses for The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Michigan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 35% increase in occupancy expense during 2007 to
    $13.2&#160;million, compared to $9.8&#160;million in 2006 is due
    to the relocation and improvement of offices, including the
    addition of new offices in Georgia and Kansas City, and
    additional office space in St.&#160;Louis and Chicago at several
    locations. Occupancy expense for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 increased 30% to $9.8&#160;million
    compared to $7.5&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005 due to the relocation of the
    Company&#146;s headquarters to larger space and the opening of
    the Chesterfield office in St.&#160;Louis.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Professional fees, which include fees paid for legal,
    accounting, consulting, and information systems consulting
    services, increased 74% to $11.9&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2007, from $6.8&#160;million for 2006 and from
    $4.6&#160;million for 2005. The increase is primarily due to
    higher legal and consulting fees to support various strategic
    initiatives as a result of the continued growth and expansion of
    the Company, including $2.5&#160;million in legal fees related
    to the implementation of the Strategic Growth Plan, and
    increased fees paid for external and internal audit services.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Investment management fees, which are fees paid to third party
    investment managers, increased 29% to $3.4&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2007, from $2.7&#160;million in
    2006 and $1.1&#160;million in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    43
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    2005. This increase is due to the increase in assets managed by
    The PrivateWealth Group during 2007 and 2006 and from the
    restructuring of certain fee relationships. The PrivateWealth
    Group&#146;s assets under management increased by 16%, or
    $459.0&#160;million, to $3.4&#160;billion at December&#160;31,
    2007 as compared to $2.9&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Marketing expense increased 42% to $6.1&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2007, compared to $4.3&#160;million
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 and $3.5&#160;million
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005. The increase in
    marketing expense reflects an increase in marketing initiatives
    for client development, website upgrading, and charitable
    contributions. The increase in 2007 is also related to
    additional marketing expenses related to the addition of new
    offices in Georgia and Kansas City as well as receptions at a
    number of offices that were relocated.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Data processing costs, which include fees paid for information
    technology services and support, increased 27% to
    $4.2&#160;million in 2007, compared to $3.3&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006, and $2.8&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2005. The growth in 2007 is due to
    investments in technology across the Company, processor
    conversion, expansion expenses in association with the new
    employees hired during the fourth quarter and the addition of
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia. During 2006, the main focus
    of information technology expenditures was in two areas. The
    information technology infrastructure was upgraded in
    association with the multiple office relocations that occurred
    during the year and The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago
    implemented a Storage Area Network solution to improve storage
    capacity and document retrieval. In 2005, we upgraded the
    existing wire transfer system in Chicago, implemented an
    enhanced data replication and recovery solution, and further
    strengthened our data management strategy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2007, we amortized $966,000 in intangible assets, $170,000 of
    which is related to our acquisition of a controlling interest in
    Lodestar in 2002, $423,000 of which is related to our
    acquisition of The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan in June
    2005, and $373,000 of which is related to the acquisition of
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia in December 2006.
    During 2006, we amortized $628,000 in intangible assets,
    $170,000 of which is related to our acquisition of Lodestar,
    $440,000 of which is related to our acquisition of
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, and $18,000 of which
    is related to the acquisition of
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia. In 2005, we amortized
    $411,000 in intangible assets, $168,000 of which is related to
    our acquisition of Lodestar and $243,000 of which is related to
    our acquisition of The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan in
    June 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The other expense category of non-interest expense includes
    $2.2&#160;million in expenses paid during 2007 relating to the
    resolution of OREO, including legal expenses and writedowns on
    OREO properties. The other expense category also includes loan
    and collection expenses, which include legal fees relating to
    the workout of non-performing loans, and totaled $466,000 at
    December&#160;31, 2007. In 2006, other expenses included the
    asset write-off related to the employee fraud loss that occurred
    during the fourth quarter of 2006. The total expense incurred
    from the fraud loss was $1.2&#160;million, of which $918,000
    related to the asset write-off in other expense and $300,000
    related to professional fees for investigating the loss.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table shows our operating efficiency over the last
    three years:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 12%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Non-interest expense less non-interest income divided by average
    total assets.</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Non-interest expense divided by the sum of net interest income,
    on a tax equivalent basis, plus non-interest income. Please
    refer to the footnotes on page&#160;34 for a reconciliation of
    net interest income to net interest income on a tax-equivalent
    basis.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    44
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our efficiency ratio (on a tax-equivalent basis), which measures
    the percentage of net revenue that is expended as non-interest
    expense, for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007 increased to
    77.2%, as compared to 54.5% for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2006, and 52.4% for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005. Our
    efficiency ratio during 2007 reflects the impact of the higher
    level of non-interest expenses associated with the
    implementation of our Strategic Growth Plan during the third and
    fourth quarters of 2007. On a tax-equivalent basis, this ratio
    indicates that during 2007 we spent 77&#160;cents to generate
    each dollar of revenue, compared to 54&#160;cents in 2006 and 52
    cents in 2005. The Company incurred over $18.1&#160;million of
    non-interest expenses related to the Strategic Growth Plan and
    booked $16.9&#160;million in provision for loan losses expense
    during the year, in part associated with credit quality
    deterioration in the existing portfolio. Largely as a result of
    the Plan, professional fees and occupancy expenses increased 74%
    and 35% year over year, respectively. During 2008, we expect
    salary expenses and occupancy costs to continue to increase.
    Accordingly, our efficiency ratio will remain at higher than
    historical levels. With continued strong growth in the balance
    sheet and fee income over the course of 2008 and 2009, and as we
    more fully lever the investments made pursuant to the Plan, we
    expect our efficiency ratio to incrementally decrease to
    historical levels.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Minority Interest
    Expense</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;30, 2002, The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Chicago acquired an 80% controlling interest in Lodestar
    Investment Counsel,&#160;LLC. We record our 20% noncontrolling
    interest in Lodestar related to Lodestar&#146;s results of
    operations in minority interest expense on our consolidated
    statement of income. For the years ended December&#160;31, 2007
    and 2006, we recorded $363,000 and $330,000 of minority interest
    expense, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Off-Balance Sheet
    Arrangements and other Contractual Obligations and
    Commitments</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We do not have material off-balance sheet arrangements. We have
    various financial obligations, including contractual obligations
    and commitments that may require future cash payments on debt
    and lease arrangements, contractual commitments for capital
    expenditures, and service contracts. The following table
    presents, as of December&#160;31, 2007, significant fixed and
    determinable contractual obligations to third parties which are
    expected to become due and payable during the period specified.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    45
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Excludes obligations to pay interest on deposits and borrowings</TD>
</TR>




<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes $1.6&#160;million of unamortized broker commissions</TD>
</TR>




<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (3) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    See consolidated financial statements commencing on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">page&#160;F-4.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our operating lease obligations represent short- and long-term
    lease and rental payments for facilities, equipment, and certain
    software or data processing. During 2007, we entered into new
    lease agreements for our Kansas City office, opened an
    additional office in Alpharetta, Georgia, and additional space
    for our Chesterfield, Missouri location. In Chicago, we leased
    additional space for our Lake&#160;Forest location and leased
    additional floor space at our headquarters to accommodate many
    of the new hires made during the fourth quarter 2007. During
    2008, we expect to lease additional office space in Chicago and
    other markets to accommodate anticipated additional hires.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our purchase obligations include obligations to pay vendors
    through contractual arrangements and also service contract
    obligations for compensation owed to employees. Commitments to
    extend credit, including loan commitments, standby letters of
    credit, and commercial letters of credit do not necessarily
    represent future cash requirements, because these commitments
    may expire without being drawn upon. Information on commitments
    and letters of credit can be found on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">page&#160;F-40.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our commitments to fund civic and community investments, which
    represent future cash outlays for the construction and
    development of properties for low-income housing, small business
    real estate, and historic tax credit projects that qualify for
    CRA purposes, are not included in the contractual obligations
    table above. The timing and amounts of these commitments are
    projected based upon the financing arrangements provided in each
    project&#146;s partnership or operating agreement, and could
    change due to variances in the construction schedule, project
    revisions, or the cancellation of the project. We continue to
    reach out to every market we serve through our community
    development efforts.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    46
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Income
    Taxes</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table shows our income before income taxes,
    applicable income taxes and effective tax rate for the years
    ended December&#160;31, 2007, 2006, and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="68%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The effective income tax rate varies from statutory rates
    principally due to certain interest income that is tax-exempt
    for federal or state purposes, and certain expenses that are
    disallowed for tax purposes. The decrease in the effective tax
    rate for 2007 compared to 2006 is a result of an increase in the
    proportion of tax-exempt income compared to income before taxes.
    The decrease in the effective tax rate for 2006 compared to 2005
    is primarily the result of the release of certain reserves
    mostly due to the expiration of the statute of limitations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Operating
    Segments Results</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the fourth quarter 2007, we aggregated our geographical
    banking segments into one Banking segment in accordance with
    paragraph&#160;17 of FASB Statement No.&#160;131, Disclosures
    about Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information
    (&#147;Statement&#160;131&#148;). As explained in the section
    captioned &#147;Business,&#148; changes in management made
    during the quarter modified the way management views its
    business segments. All geographical banking locations outside of
    Chicago, whose operations are very similar, whose economic
    performance we measure consistently and whose products and
    services and client base are similar, report through one
    Executive Committee member to the Chief Executive Officer. As
    such, and as described in Note&#160;2 to the consolidated
    financial statements, our operations consist of three primary
    business segments: Banking; The PrivateWealth Group; and the
    Holding Company. The PrivateBank Mortgage Company results are
    included with the Banking segment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Banking</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The profitability of each of our bank subsidiaries is primarily
    dependent on net interest income, provision for loan losses,
    non-interest income and non-interest expense. Net income for the
    banking segment for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007
    decreased 33% to $32.3&#160;million from $48.5&#160;million for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2006. The decrease in net
    income for the banking segment resulted primarily from expenses
    associated with the implementation of our Strategic Growth Plan,
    including significant compensation-related expense. Net income
    for the banking segment for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2006 increased 23% to $48.5&#160;million from $39.4&#160;million
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005. Net interest income
    for the banking segment for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2007 increased to $140.3&#160;million from $124.1&#160;million
    in 2006 and from $98.9&#160;million in 2005. Total loans for the
    banking segment increased by 19% to $4.2&#160;billion during
    2007 as compared to $3.5&#160;billion in 2006. The majority of
    the loan growth for 2007 occurred in the commercial, commercial
    real estate, and owner-occupied commercial real estate loan
    categories. Total deposits increased by 11% to $4.0&#160;billion
    at December&#160;31, 2007 from $3.6&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2006. Growth in other time deposits and
    interest bearing demand deposits accounted for the majority of
    the deposit growth.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">The
    PrivateWealth Group</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The PrivateWealth Group includes investment management, personal
    trust and estate services, custodial services, retirement
    accounts and brokerage and investment services. The
    PrivateWealth Group&#146;s assets under management increased by
    16%, or $459.0&#160;million, to $3.4&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2007 as compared to $2.9&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2006. This growth was due to the addition of
    new
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    47
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    assets under management as well as portfolio performance. The
    PrivateWealth Group&#146;s fee revenue increased to
    $16.2&#160;million, or 17%, for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2007 compared to $13.9&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 and $9.9&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005. Net income for The PrivateWealth Group
    decreased 6% to $1.6&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2007 from $1.7&#160;million for the same
    period in 2006, and up from $967,000 for the same period in
    2005. This decrease was mainly due to an increase in personnel
    and occupancy expenses attributable to The PrivateWealth
    Group&#146;s operations initiated in Kansas City and new
    brokerage operations initiated in Chicago.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following tables indicate the breakdown of The PrivateWealth
    Group&#146;s assets under management at December&#160;31, 2007
    and December&#160;31, 2006, by account classification and
    related gross revenue for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007
    and December&#160;31, 2006:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 12%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Fiduciary Services includes accounts administered at
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago and
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan.
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago also provides fiduciary
    services delivered in The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Wisconsin, The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St.&#160;Louis, and
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Kansas City.</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    These assets are held in Fiduciary Services accounts at
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago and
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For a number of our wealth management relationships, we utilize
    third-party investment managers, including Lodestar. Fees paid
    to third party investment managers increased to
    $3.4&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007,
    compared to $2.7&#160;million for same period in 2006, and
    $1.1&#160;million for the same period in 2005. Fees paid to
    Lodestar totaled approximately $535,000 in 2007. Of our
    third-party investment managers, none individually managed more
    than 5% of total wealth management assets under management as of
    December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Holding
    Company</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Holding Company activities consist of parent company only
    matters. The Holding Company&#146;s most significant assets are
    its net investments in its five banking subsidiaries,
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago,
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St.&#160;Louis (which includes
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Kansas City), The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan,
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin,
    The&#160;PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, and our mortgage
    banking subsidiary, The&#160;PrivateBank Mortgage Company.
    Holding Company activities are reflected primarily by
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    48
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    interest expense on borrowings and operating expenses of the
    parent company. Recurring holding company operating expenses
    consist primarily of compensation (amortization of restricted
    stock and stock awards and stock option expense) and
    professional fees. The Holding Company segment reported a net
    loss of $21.3&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2007, compared to a net loss of $11.8&#160;million for the same
    period in 2006. For the year ended December&#160;31, 2005 the
    Holding Company activities segment reported a net loss of
    $7.0&#160;million. The increase in net loss year over year is
    primarily due to an increase in interest expense related to the
    issuance of $115.0&#160;million contingent convertible senior
    notes during the first quarter 2007 and increased legal and
    external audit fees at the holding company level due to the
    continued growth of the Company.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">FINANCIAL
    CONDITION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Total
    Assets</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total assets were $5.0&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2007,
    an increase of $725.8&#160;million, or 17%, from
    $4.3&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006. The balance sheet
    growth was accomplished mainly through 19% loan growth
    throughout the Company year over year. The growth in assets
    experienced during 2007 was funded through the issuance of
    $200.0&#160;million of equity capital, growth of core deposits,
    and borrowings under the Company&#146;s credit facility.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Loans</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total gross loans increased to $4.2&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2007, an increase of $677.8&#160;million or
    19%, from $3.5&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006. The two
    largest loan categories, commercial and commercial real estate,
    grew by 58% and 8%, respectively. For 2006 and 2007, the
    commercial loan category includes both commercial and industrial
    loans and owner-occupied commercial real estate loans. For
    periods prior to 2006, owner-occupied commercial real estate was
    included in the commercial real estate category. At year-end
    2007, total owner-occupied commercial real estate loans were
    $483.9&#160;million or 12% of total loans, and
    $265.4&#160;million or 8% of total loans at year-end 2006. From
    December&#160;31, 2006 to December&#160;31, 2007, construction
    loans grew by 4% and private banking loans, which include
    residential real estate, personal, and home equity loans, grew
    by 9%.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth the loan portfolio by category as
    of December 31 for the previous five fiscal years:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 7pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="25%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=05 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=05 type=lead -->
    <TD width="4%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=05 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=05 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=06 type=gutter -->

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes adjustable rate mortgage products.</TD>

    (2) </TD>

    Total includes $11,000 of overdrafts.</TD>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth the composition of our
    construction and commercial real estate loan portfolio, net of
    unearned discount, by property type and collateral location at
    December&#160;31, 2007. Construction loans totaled
    $613.5&#160;million and commercial real estate loans totaled
    $1.6&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Allowance for
    Loan Losses</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Loan quality is monitored by management and reviewed by the
    committees of the Board of Directors at our regular board
    meetings. The amount of additions to the allowance for loan
    losses, which is charged to earnings through the provision for
    loan losses, is determined based on a variety of factors,
    including assessment of the credit risk of the loans in the
    portfolio, delinquent loans, impaired loans, evaluation of
    current economic conditions in the market area, actual
    charge-offs and recoveries during the period, industry loss
    averages and historical loss experience. The unallocated portion
    of the reserve involves the exercise of judgment by management
    and reflects various considerations, including management&#146;s
    view that the reserve should have a margin that recognizes the
    imprecision inherent in the process of estimating credit losses.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    50
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We maintain an allowance for loan losses sufficient to absorb
    credit losses inherent in our loan portfolio. The allowance for
    loan losses represents our estimate of probable losses in the
    portfolio at each balance sheet date and is supported by
    available and relevant information. The allowance contains
    provisions for probable losses that have been identified
    relating to specific borrowing relationships, as well as
    probable losses inherent in the loan portfolio and credit
    undertakings that are not specifically identified.
    Management&#146;s application of the methodology for determining
    the allowance for loan losses resulted in an allowance for loan
    losses of $48.9&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2007 compared
    with $38.1&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006. The increase
    in the allowance for loan losses from December&#160;31, 2006
    reflects management&#146;s judgment about the comprehensive risk
    of lending in our various markets, the addition of new lending
    personnel as well as strong loan growth from all offices in
    2007. We believe that the allowance for loan losses is adequate
    to provide for probable and reasonably estimable credit losses
    inherent in our loan portfolio.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans was
    1.17% at December&#160;31, 2007, up from 1.09% at
    December&#160;31, 2006. Net charge-offs totaled
    $6.1&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2007
    compared to $873,000 for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006.
    The provision for loan losses was $16.9&#160;million for the
    twelve months ended December&#160;31, 2007, versus
    $6.8&#160;million in the prior year period. The key factors in
    determining the level of provision is our historical and
    anticipated charge-off rates and an analysis of credit ratings
    on the loans in our portfolio.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table shows changes in the allowance for loan
    losses resulting from additions to the allowance, loan
    charge-offs and recoveries for each of the periods shown.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We considered various qualitative and quantitative factors about
    the loan portfolio in determining the level of the allowance for
    loan losses. Under our methodology, the allowance for loan
    losses is comprised of the following components:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Allocated
    Inherent Component of the Reserve</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The allocated portion of the allowance for loan losses is based
    on loan type and allocated by loan risk within each loan type.
    The Company assigns each of its loans a risk rating at the time
    of loan origination and either confirms or changes the risk
    rating at the time of subsequent reviews, loan renewals or upon
    default. The loss allocations are based on a combination of a
    historical analysis of the Company&#146;s losses and adjustment
    factors deemed relevant by management. The adjustment factors
    take into account banking industry-wide loss statistics, current
    facts and circumstances, and long-term economic trends.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The allocated inherent component of the reserve increased by
    $8.4&#160;million during 2007, from $35.6&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 to $44.0&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2007. The increase in the allocated portion of
    the reserve reflects higher loan volumes in every category,
    particularly commercial loans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Specific
    Component of the Reserve</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For loans where management deems either the amount or the timing
    of the repayment to be significantly impaired, there are
    specific reserve allocations established. The specific reserve
    is based on a loan&#146;s current value compared to the present
    value of its projected future cash flows, collateral value or
    market value, as is relevant for the particular loan pursuant to
    SFAS&#160;114, &#147;Accounting by Creditors for Impairment of a
    Loan.&#148; At December&#160;31, 2007, after taking into account
    $6.1&#160;million in net charge offs during the year, the
    specific component of the reserve increased by $8.8&#160;million
    to $3.0&#160;million from $291,000 at December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    52
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Unallocated
    Inherent Components of the Reserve</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The unallocated inherent component of the reserve is based on
    management&#146;s review of other factors affecting the
    determination of probable losses inherent in the portfolio,
    which are not necessarily captured by the application of loss
    and loss adjustment factors. This portion of the reserve
    analysis involves the exercise of judgment and reflects
    consideration such as management&#146;s view that the reserve
    should have a margin that recognizes the imprecision inherent in
    the process of estimating credit losses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The unallocated inherent component of the reserve decreased by
    $255,000 for 2007, from $2.1&#160;million at December&#160;31,
    2006 to $1.9&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2007. In early
    2007, we decreased the unallocated component of our reserve due
    to our judgment that all problem loans had been identified and
    were specifically reserved for. As credit quality deteriorated
    throughout the second, third and fourth quarters, we increased
    our unallocated reserves to $1.9&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Non-performing
    Loans</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table classifies our non-performing loans as of
    the dates shown:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #CCEEFF">

    Total non-performing loans to total loans
</DIV>
