<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 12%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The intersegment eliminations for interest expense reflect the
    elimination of the holding company&#146;s cash deposited at The
    PrivateBanks&#160;&#150; Chicago, St.&#160;Louis and Georgia.
    The intersegment eliminations include adjustments necessary for
    each category to agree with the related consolidated financial
    statements.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Banking</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The PrivateBanks&#160;&#150; Chicago, St.&#160;Louis, Wisconsin,
    Michigan and Georgia, provide personal and commercial banking
    services primarily to affluent individuals, professionals,
    entrepreneurs and their business interests. Commercial lending
    products include lines of credit for working capital, term loans
    for equipment and letters of credit to support the commitments
    made by its clients. Non-credit products include remote capture,
    merchant credit card processing, electronic funds transfer, and
    other cash management products. In addition, some of our banks
    provide lock-box and cash concentration accounts. The banks
    offer a full range of real estate lending products including
    fixed and floating rate permanent and mini-permanent mortgages,
    and construction and commercial real estate loans. Personal
    loans include installment loans and lines of credit, home equity
    loans and a wide variety of home mortgage loans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Personal banking services include interest-bearing checking,
    money market accounts, certificates of deposit, ATM/debit cards,
    investment brokerage accounts and domestic and international
    wire transfers. Additionally, some of our banks offer secured
    and unsecured personal loans and lines of credit, foreign
    currency exchange and access to wealth management services and
    products.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2001, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago recorded
    approximately $12.2&#160;million in goodwill in connection with
    the Johnson Bank Illinois acquisition. During 2002, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago recorded $8.4&#160;million of
    goodwill and $2.5&#160;million in customer intangibles in
    connection with the Lodestar acquisition. The customer
    intangibles reflect the estimated fair value of the Lodestar
    client relationships over a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">15-year</FONT> time
    horizon. On June&#160;15, 2004, The PrivateBank Mortgage Company
    recorded $1.3&#160;million in goodwill in connection with the
    acquisition of Corley Financial Services. The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago&#146;s balance sheet reflects
    goodwill of $19.2&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2007, which
    remained unchanged from December&#160;31, 2006, and intangibles
    of $1.7&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2007, compared to
    $1.9&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006. Amortization
    expense related to the Lodestar customer intangible assets is
    currently recognized at approximately $170,000 per year until
    2017.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the second quarter 2005, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Michigan recorded $42.6&#160;million in goodwill,
    $3.2&#160;million of client deposit intangibles and $500,000 of
    wealth management intangibles in connection with the
    Company&#146;s acquisition of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Michigan. The amortization expense related to The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan intangibles are amortized over
    10&#160;years using an accelerated method of amortization. The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan balance sheet reflects goodwill
    of $42.6&#160;million, which remained unchanged from
    December&#160;31, 2006, and intangibles of $2.7&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2007, compared to $3.1&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006. The amortization expense related to The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    F-17
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Michigan intangibles for the years 2008 through 2012, will be
    approximately $406,000, $389,000, $373,000, $358,000, and
    $343,000, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the fourth quarter 2006, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Georgia recorded $29.9&#160;million in goodwill,
    $2.5&#160;million of client deposit intangibles in connection
    with the Company&#146;s acquisition of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia. The amortization expense
    related to The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia will be amortized
    over 8&#160;years using an accelerated method of amortization.
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia&#146;s balance sheet
    reflects goodwill of $30.2&#160;million, compared to
    $29.9&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006 due to routine
    adjustments of deferred taxes and acquisition costs related to
    the purchase of The PrivateBank-Georgia as allowable under
    accounting rules. The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia had
    intangibles of $2.1&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2007
    compared to $2.5&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006, as a
    result of its acquisition by the Company on December&#160;13,
    2006. The amortization expense related to The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia intangibles for the years 2008
    through 2012, will be approximately $355,000, $338,000,
    $320,000, $302,000, and $284,000, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    There was no goodwill or intangible impairment at
    December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">The PrivateWealth
    Group</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The PrivateWealth Group (formerly &#147;Wealth Management&#148;)
    includes investment management, personal trust, and estate
    administration, custodial, qualified plan, IRA, brokerage and
    investment advisory services. The PrivateWealth Group
    professionals work with trust and investment management clients
    to define objectives, goals and strategies for clients&#146;
    investment portfolios. They also assist some clients with the
    selection of independent investment managers to handle account
    investments. In addition, account administrators work with trust
    clients and their attorneys to establish estate plans.
    Consistent with the Company&#146;s philosophy, The PrivateWealth
    Group emphasizes a high level of personal service, including
    prompt collection and reinvestment of interest and dividend
    income, daily portfolio valuations, tracking of tax information,
    customized reporting and ease of security settlement. Lodestar
    is an investment management firm that is 80% owned by The
    PrivateBank and Trust&#160;Company and is part of The
    PrivateWealth Group for segment reporting purposes. Lodestar
    provides investment management services to high net worth
    clients, some of whom are also fiduciary services clients of The
    PrivateWealth Group. The minority interest expense related to
    Lodestar is included in non-interest expense for this segment.
    Additionally, clients have access to investment advisory,
    insurance products, and securities brokerage services through an
    affiliation each of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St.&#160;Louis, and The PrivateBank -
    Michigan has with Linsco Private Ledger, a registered broker
    dealer and registered investment advisor.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the year ended December&#160;31, 2007, fees paid to third
    party investment managers were $3.4&#160;million compared to
    $2.7&#160;million in the prior year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Holding
    Company</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Holding Company activities consist of parent company only
    matters. The Holding Company&#146;s most significant assets are
    net investments in its five banking subsidiaries, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    St.&#160;Louis, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, and The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia and a mortgage company
    subsidiary, The PrivateBank Mortgage Company. The Holding
    Company acquired The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia on
    December&#160;13, 2006, as part of its acquisition of Piedmont
    Bancshares, Inc.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Holding Company activities are reflected primarily by interest
    expense on borrowings and operating expenses. Recurring Holding
    Company operating expenses consist of compensation (amortization
    of restricted stock awards and stock option expense) and
    professional fees.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-18
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2007, 741,965 of 2,575,304 unexercised options are
    included in the diluted earnings per common share calculation.
    During 2006, 1,128,551 of 1,550,451 unexercised options are
    included in the diluted earnings per common share calculation.
    During 2005, 1,526,350 of 1,540,350 unexercised options are
    included in the diluted earnings per common share calculation.
    The exercise prices for all previously granted unexercised stock
    options ranged from $4.13 to $46.51 in 2007, $3.65 to $46.51 in
    2006, and from $3.13 to $37.56 in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Not included in the diluted earnings per share calculation are
    shares that are contingently issuable. Contingently issuable
    shares are any type of equity that will be issued by the Company
    once a particular contingency has been met. At December&#160;31,
    2007, the Company had 1,158,073 of contingently issuable shares
    related to share based compensation and 2,552,724 of
    contingently issuable shares related to convertible debt. The
    Company had no contingently issuable shares at December&#160;31,
    2006 and December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-19
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table presents the age of gross unrealized losses
    and fair value by investment category (in thousands).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="39%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="6%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=lead -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Management does not believe any individual unrealized loss as of
    December&#160;31, 2007 represents an
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">other-than-temporary</FONT>
    impairment. The unrealized losses over 12&#160;months reported
    for mortgage-backed securities and collateralized mortgage
    obligations relate primarily to securities issued by FNMA, FHLMC
    and private institutions. These unrealized losses over
    12&#160;months are primarily attributable to changes in interest
    rates.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The amortized cost and estimated fair value of securities at
    December&#160;31, 2007, by expected maturity, are shown below
    (in thousands). Expected maturities will differ from contractual
    maturities because obligors may have the right to call or prepay
    obligations with or without call or prepayment penalties. Our
    U.S.&#160;Government Agency Mortgage-Backed Securities and
    Collateralized Mortgage Obligations have been allocated across
    the various maturities based on Bloomberg consensus prepayment
    speeds.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2007 and 2006, securities were sold for total proceeds of
    $13.7&#160;million and $108.3&#160;million respectively,
    resulting in net gains of approximately $348,000 for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2007 and net losses of approximately
    $374,000 for December&#160;31, 2006. Gross gains and gross
    losses for 2007 were $390,000 and $42,000, respectively. Gross
    gains and gross losses for 2006 were $2.0&#160;million and
    $2.4&#160;million, respectively. Taxes related to gross gains
    and gross losses on investment securities for 2007 were $148,000
    and ($10,000), respectively. Taxes related to gross gains and
    gross losses on investment securities for 2006 were $728,000 and
    ($867,000), respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Premium amortization and discount accretion on securities are
    included in interest income on securities using the effective
    interest rate method. Premium amortizations totaled
    $3.1&#160;million, $3.2&#160;million, and $6.0&#160;million for
    the years ended December&#160;31, 2007, 2006, and 2005,
    respectively. Discount accretion totaled $2.2&#160;million,
    $1.8&#160;million, and $1.7&#160;million at December&#160;31,
    2007, 2006, and 2005, respectively. The specific identification
    method is used to record gains and losses on security
    transactions.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    F-21
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2007 and 2006, we had approximately
    $398.6&#160;million and $359.5&#160;million, respectively, of
    securities collateralizing public deposits, trust deposits and
    other collateralized deposits for other purposes as required or
    permitted by law. Deposits requiring pledged assets are not
    considered to be core deposits for regulatory purposes and the
    assets that are pledged as collateral for these deposits are not
    deemed to be liquid assets. In the opinion of management, there
    were no investments in securities at December&#160;31, 2007 that
    constituted an unusual credit risk for the Company.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Change in fair value of securities
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    is presented on a net basis in the Consolidated Statement of
    Changes in Stockholders&#146; Equity. The following table
    discloses the changes in other comprehensive income as of

</DIV>

<TR valign="top">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTE&#160;5&#151;</FONT></B>

</TD>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Amounts outstanding by selected loan categories at
    December&#160;31, 2007 and 2006, including net unamortized
    deferred loan fees of $2.2&#160;million and $1.7&#160;million,
    respectively, were as follows (in thousands):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have one restructured loan in the portfolio as of
    December&#160;31, 2007. Management has granted a concession to a
    borrower experiencing financial difficulty on a
    $2.1&#160;million loan. Gross interest income that would have
    been reported in 2007 had the loan performed in accordance with
    its original terms was $96,000 and interest income included in
    2007 net income was $142,000. The Company has no commitments to
    lend additional funds to this borrower.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Loan concentrations are defined as amounts loaned to a multiple
    number of borrowers engaged in similar activities, which would
    cause them to be similarly impacted by economic or other
    conditions. The banks grant loans to clients located primarily
    in the metropolitan Chicago, St.&#160;Louis, Milwaukee, Detroit,
    Kansas City, and Atlanta areas. There are no other significant
    concentrations of loans and commitments to make loans other than
    the categories of loans disclosed above. At December&#160;31,
    2007, we had $180.5&#160;million in loans pledged to the FHLB as
    collateral for securing our advances.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, we added $202.9&#160;million of loans and
    $2.7&#160;million of allowance for loan loss from The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia at its acquisition date,
    December&#160;30, 2006. In 2005, we added $315.6&#160;million of
    loans and $3.6&#160;million of allowance for loan loss from The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan at its acquisition date.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-23

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total rent expense, including expenses paid for common area
    maintenance, included in the consolidated statements of income
    was $6.0&#160;million, $4.5&#160;million, and $3.3&#160;million,
    in 2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTE&#160;8&#151;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">INCOME
    TAXES</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    consolidated statements of income for the years ended
    December&#160;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005 are as follows (in
    thousands):

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Deferred tax assets and liabilities result from temporary
    differences between the carrying amounts of assets and
    liabilities in the financial statements and their related tax
    bases. The components of the net deferred tax balances as of
    December&#160;31, 2007 and 2006 are as follows (in thousands):

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net deferred tax assets are included in other assets in the
    Company&#146;s Consolidated Balance Sheets. Included in net
    deferred tax assets at December&#160;31, 2006 is approximately
    $767,000 of net deferred tax assets acquired in the purchase of
    Piedmont Bancshares, Inc. These net deferred tax assets include
    a net operating loss carryforward of approximately $147,000
    which expires in 2026. The Company believes it is more likely
    than not that the deferred tax assets including the net
    operating loss carryforward will be realized based on reversing
    deferred tax liabilities and expected future taxable income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As discussed in Note&#160;1, &#147;Basis of Presentation,&#148;
    the Company adopted FIN&#160;48 as of January&#160;1, 2007. As
    of the date of adoption, there were no unrecognized tax benefits
    included in the consolidated balance sheet. Accordingly, there
    were no amounts recognized for potential penalties and interest
    related
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-25
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    to unrecognized tax benefits. If incurred, the Company would
    recognize any interest and penalties in the provision for income
    taxes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company files U.S.&#160;federal and various state income tax
    returns. The Company is no longer subject to income tax
    examination by the Federal Internal Revenue Service (IRS) or
    certain state departments of revenue with which it files for
    years prior to 2004. Although tax year 2004&#160;may still be
    subject to examination due to the statute of limitations, the
    IRS has previously completed its review of the U.S.&#160;federal
    tax returns for this year. Similarly, while tax years 2003
    through 2005&#160;may still be subject to examination due to the
    statute of limitations, the Illinois Department of Revenue has
    previously completed its review of the Illinois state tax
    returns for these years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 12%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Demand repurchase agreements are a form of retail repurchase
    agreements offered to certain clients of The
    PrivateBank&#151;Chicago and The
    PrivateBank&#151;St.&#160;Louis. Funds are swept each business
    day from the client&#146;s demand deposit account. These amounts
    are not deposits and are not insured, but are secured by a pool
    of securities pledged specifically for this purpose.</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the acquisitions of the Michigan and Georgia
    banks, we acquired certain FHLB advances; the difference between
    the fair value and the book value at acquisition date is being
    amortized over 10&#160;years and 8&#160;years, respectively,
    using an accelerated method of amortization. The adjustments at
    December&#160;31, 2007 and 2006 totaled $15,000 and $37,000,
    respectively, and are not included in the balances above.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    F-27
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 12%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In connection with the acquisitions of the Michigan and Georgia
    banks, we acquired certain FHLB advances; the difference between
    the fair value and the book value at acquisition date is being
    amortized over 10&#160;years and 8&#160;years, respectively,
    using an accelerated method of amortization. The adjustments at
    December&#160;31, 2007 and 2006 totaled $15,000 and $37,000,
    respectively, and are not included in the balances above.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2007 the Company owned 100% of the
    common securities of three trusts, PrivateBancorp Statutory
    Trust&#160;II, Bloomfield Hills Statutory Trust&#160;I and
    PrivateBancorp Statutory Trust&#160;III (the
    &#147;Trusts&#148;). PrivateBancorp Statutory Trust&#160;II and
    PrivateBancorp Statutory Trust&#160;III were established as
    wholly-owned subsidiaries of the Company in June 2005 and
    December 2005, respectively. Bloomfield Hills Statutory
    Trust&#160;I was acquired as part of our acquisition of
    Bloomfield Hills Bancorp, Inc. (&#147;BHB&#148;) on
    June&#160;20, 2005. The Trusts were formed for purposes of
    issuing trust preferred securities to third-party investors and
    investing the proceeds from the issuance of the trust preferred
    securities and common securities solely in junior subordinated
    debentures (&#147;Debentures&#148;) issued by the Trusts, with
    the same maturities and interest rates as the trust preferred
    securities. The Debentures are the sole assets of the Trusts.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    F-29
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 12%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    6.00% rate effective until 9/15/2010, then floating at
    three-month LIBOR + 1.71%.</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    6.10% rate effective until 12/15/2010, then floating at
    three-month LIBOR + 1.50%.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On June&#160;20, 2005, PrivateBancorp Statutory Trust&#160;II
    issued $50.0&#160;million in fixed/floating rate trust preferred
    securities. The trust preferred securities pay interest
    quarterly at a fixed rate of 6.00% for the initial five years
    and then will subsequently pay interest quarterly at a floating
    rate equal to 3&#160;month LIBOR plus 1.71%. The trust preferred
    securities have a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">30-year</FONT>
    final maturity and are callable at par at the option of the
    Company in whole or in part after year five, on any interest
    payment date.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the acquisition of BHB, the Company acquired
    $8.0&#160;million in floating rate junior subordinated debenture
    trust preferred securities issued by Bloomfield Hills Statutory
    Trust&#160;I. The trust preferred securities pay interest
    quarterly at a rate of 3&#160;month LIBOR plus 2.65%. The trust
    preferred securities have a maturity date of June&#160;17, 2034
    and are callable beginning June&#160;17, 2009 and at any
    interest payment date thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;5, 2005, PrivateBancorp Statutory
    Trust&#160;III issued $40.0&#160;million of trust preferred
    securities and related junior subordinated debentures. These
    securities mature in December 2035 but are redeemable at par at
    our option after five years. The trust preferred securities pay
    quarterly distributions at a rate of 6.10% for five years and
    thereafter at a rate equal to the three-month LIBOR rate plus
    1.50%. A portion of the proceeds was used to fund the
    redemption, on December&#160;31, 2005 of $20.0&#160;million of
    previously outstanding 9.50% trust preferred securities that
    were originally issued in 2001.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Trusts, which are variable interest entities, are reported
    in the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements as
    unconsolidated subsidiaries. Accordingly, the Debentures, which
    include the Company&#146;s ownership interest in the Trusts, are
    reflected as &#147;Junior Subordinated deferrable interest
    Debentures held by trusts that issued guaranteed capital debt
    securities&#148; on the face of the balance sheet and the common
    securities are included in &#147;other assets.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has guaranteed the payment of distributions and
    payments upon liquidation or redemption of the Debentures, in
    each case to the extent of funds held by the Trusts. The Company
    and the Trusts believe that, taken together, the obligations of
    the Company under the guarantees, the Debentures, and other
    related agreements provide, in the aggregate, a full,
    irrevocable and unconditional guarantee, on a subordinated
    basis, of all of the obligations of the Trusts under the trust
    preferred securities. Subject to certain limitations, the
    Company has the right to defer the payment of interest on the
    Debentures at any time, or from time to time, for a period not
    to exceed 20 consecutive quarters. The trust preferred
    securities are subject to mandatory redemption, in whole or in
    part, upon repayment
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-30
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    of the Debentures at maturity or their earlier redemption. The
    Debentures are redeemable in whole or in part prior to maturity
    at any time after the dates shown in the table, and earlier at
    the discretion of the Company if certain conditions are met,
    and, in any event, only after the Company has obtained Federal
    Reserve approval, if then required under applicable guidelines
    or regulations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s aggregate principal amount of outstanding
    Debentures at December&#160;31, 2007 is $101.0&#160;million. As
    of December&#160;31, 2007, all of our Debentures are eligible
    for treatment as Tier&#160;1 capital as allowed by the Federal
    Reserve. On March&#160;1, 2005, the Federal Reserve issued a
    final rule that retains Tier&#160;1 capital treatment for trust
    preferred securities but with stricter limits. Under the rule,
    after a five-year transition period, the aggregate amount of the
    trust preferred securities and certain other capital elements
    will retain their current limit of 25% of Tier&#160;1 capital
    elements, net of goodwill less any associated deferred tax
    liability. The amount of trust preferred securities and certain
    other capital elements in excess of the limit could be included
    in Tier&#160;2 capital, subject to restrictions. Applying the
    final rule at December&#160;31, 2007, the Company would still be
    considered well-capitalized under regulatory capital guidelines.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2007 the Company had a credit facility
    with a correspondent bank comprised of a $24.75&#160;million
    senior debt facility and a $75.0&#160;million subordinated debt
    facility. The senior debt facility is comprised of a $250,000
    term loan with a maturity date of December&#160;31, 2017 and a
    revolving loan with a maturity date of December&#160;31, 2008.
    Management expects to renew the revolving loan on an annual
    basis. The subordinated debt matures on December&#160;31, 2017.
    The interest rate on the senior debt facility resets quarterly,
    and is based on, at the Company&#146;s option, either the
    correspondent bank&#146;s prime rate or three-month LIBOR plus
    120&#160;basis points, with a floor of 3.50%. The interest rate
    on the subordinated debt resets quarterly, and is equal to
    three-month LIBOR plus 135&#160;basis points, with a floor of
    3.50%. The subordinated debt qualifies as Tier&#160;2 capital
    under applicable rules and regulations promulgated by the Board
    of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2007 included in funds borrowed, the
    Company had $250,000 outstanding on the senior debt facility and
    $75.0&#160;million of subordinated debt outstanding. The credit
    facility is used for general corporate and other working capital
    purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2007, the Company issued a total of $115.0&#160;million of
    contingent convertible senior notes to qualified institutional
    investors. The notes are senior, unsecured obligations of
    PrivateBancorp, Inc. and pay interest semi-annually at a rate of
    3.625% per year. The notes will mature on March&#160;15, 2027,
    and will be convertible under certain circumstances into cash
    and, if applicable, shares of the Company&#146;s common stock at
    an initial conversion price of $45.05 per share. A portion of
    the net proceeds from the notes were used during the first
    quarter 2007 to pay down $41.5&#160;million of the senior debt
    facility and approximately $7.5&#160;million of the net proceeds
    were used to repurchase 213,200&#160;shares of common stock. The
    Company will use the remaining net proceeds for working capital
    and other general corporate purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="10%"></TD>
    <TD width="90%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTE&#160;11&#151;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">ACCOUNTING FOR
    STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION AND OTHER BENEFITS</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Equity Award
    Plans</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has several plans that it uses to issue equity based
    awards that include stock options, stock appreciation rights,
    restricted stock and restricted stock units. These plans include
    the Incentive Compensation Plan, the Stock Incentive Plan and
    the Transformation Equity Award Plan. The Transformation Equity
    Award Plan is the combination of two plans, the Strategic Long
    Term Incentive Plan and the Long Term Incentive Plan. At
    December&#160;31, 2007, the Incentive Compensation Plan had
    50,254&#160;shares available to be granted under the Plan either
    pursuant to the granting of stock options, as restricted stock
    awards or as deferred stock units. No shares remain available
    for grant under the Stock Incentive Plan. The Strategic Long
    Term Incentive Plan had 2,565,400&#160;shares available and the
    Long
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-31
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Term Incentive Plan had 3,770,368&#160;share equivalents
    available at December&#160;31, 2007. The Strategic Long Term
    Incentive Plan and the Long Term Incentive Plan were approved by
    the Board of Directors with 5,000,000 issuable units each.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Incentive
    Compensation Plan</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Equity issued from this plan will be awarded to employees that
    are not designated key managers of the company and new employees
    not included in the Strategic Growth and Transformation plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Beginning in 2006, the Company modified its retirement provision
    for awards issued under this plan. Retirement eligibility is
    defined as having completed at least ten years of employment
    with the Company (or a predecessor) and having attained at least
    62&#160;years of age. The 2006 and subsequent awards held by
    employees who retire with retirement eligibility will continue
    to vest on the normal vesting schedule so long as the retiree
    remains retired from the financial services industry. In the
    financial statements, these grants will be amortized up to the
    retirement eligibility date. Any grants awarded to employees
    already meeting the retirement definition will be immediately
    expensed on the grant date.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Transformation
    Equity Award Plan</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On November&#160;2, 2007, the Company announced its Strategic
    Growth and Transformation plan. Included with this plan is the
    Transformation Equity Award Plan (&#147;Transformation
    Plan&#148;) for making inducement awards as a means to attract
    talent and to promote the achievement of exceptional performance
    benchmarks. More than half of these awards have market based or
    performance based vesting provisions that create an incentive
    for management to achieve significant stock price appreciation
    or earnings per share growth hurdles. The remaining equity
    awards are stock options, which will vest over a five-year
    period.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Strategic Long
    Term Incentive Plan</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This plan contains inducement awards that have been and will
    continue to be granted to specific new employees hired as part
    of the Strategic Growth and Transformation plan. It is not
    required that these awards receive shareholder approval and the
    Company has no plans to do so.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Long Term
    Incentive Plan</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This plan contains retention awards that have been granted to
    certain key managers that were employed by the company prior to
    the announcement of the Strategic Growth and Transformation
    plan. These awards have the same characteristics as awards
    issued under the Strategic Long Term Incentive plan except that
    that they are currently required to be settled in cash, not
    stock, until the plan is approved by the Company&#146;s
    shareholders. As such, these awards are currently classified as
    Stock Appreciation Rights (&#147;SARs&#148;) and Restricted
    Stock Units (&#147;RSUs&#148;) and are subject to remeasurement
    per SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R). SARs and RSUs are valued and
    amortized using the same techniques as the inducement awards
    that are settled with the Company&#146;s shares. However,
    because SARs and RSUs are settled in cash, these awards are
    revalued at each reporting date and are classified as other
    liabilities in the Company&#146;s balance sheet.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Stock Options and
    SARs</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company had stock options outstanding (split-adjusted) under
    its Stock Incentive Plan, Incentive Compensation Plan and Long
    Term Incentive Plan of 293,355, 1,166,323 and 1,791,000 at
    December&#160;31, 2007, and 379,610, 1,170,841 and no options
    outstanding at December&#160;31, 2006, respectively, for each
    plan.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-32
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Included in salaries and employee benefits in the consolidated
    statements of income is compensation expense for stock options
    and SARs, net of forfeits, of $4.9&#160;million in 2007,
    $2.0&#160;million in 2006 and $2.8&#160;million in 2005. The
    total recognized tax benefit related to this compensation
    expense was $1.1&#160;million in 2007, $223,000 in 2006 and
    $251,000 in 2005. The total intrinsic value of options exercised
    was $3.5&#160;million in 2007, $9.5&#160;million in 2006, and
    $5.6&#160;million in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    All options issued under the Incentive Compensation Plan have a
    strike price equal to the per share fair market value of the
    underlying common stock on the date of grant. All options have a
    term of 10&#160;years. Beginning with stock options granted in
    the third quarter 2006, employee options vest equally over the
    first five years on each anniversary date of the grant, and
    non-employee director options vest equally over the first three
    years on each anniversary date of the grant. Options granted to
    employees prior to 2006 were first exercisable beginning on the
    second anniversary date of the grant, and then fully vested on
    the fourth anniversary date. Options awarded to non-employee
    directors prior to 2006 vested at the end of the year in which
    the awards were granted. Additionally, all options granted in
    2006 and 2007 were non-qualified stock options. Prior to 2006,
    employees were primarily granted incentive stock options and
    non-employee directors were granted non-qualified stock options.
    Due to the different rules of taxation to the option holder,
    non-qualified stock options require the Company to record a tax
    benefit related to the amortized compensation expense in its
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    All options issued under the Transformation Plan have a strike
    price equal to the per share fair market value of the underlying
    common stock on the date of grant. All options have a term of
    10&#160;years. Beginning in 2008, options will vest annually
    based upon the achievement of 20% compounded annual growth in
    GAAP fully dilutive earnings per share from a baseline of $1.65,
    the EPS for the twelve months prior to September&#160;30, 2007.
    If the annual target is not attained, these options will vest
    based upon the achievement of cumulative earnings per share
    growth hurdles over the baseline: 50%, 75% and 100% will vest if
    the sum of GAAP earnings per share is equivalent to compounded
    annual growth rates in earnings per share of 15%, 17.5% and 20%,
    respectively, over a five-year time period ending
    December&#160;31, 2012. If none of these targets are achieved,
    25% of the options originally issued will vest if the recipient
    is still employed by the Company on December&#160;31, 2012. In
    no circumstance will more than 100% of the originally issued
    options vest. All options granted were non-qualified stock
    options.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since vesting is mostly dependent on EPS targets, the
    Transformation options contain a performance condition as
    defined by SFAS&#160;123R. At each reporting period the Company
    must assess the probability of these shares vesting based on the
    performance conditions. The compensation expense in the
    Company&#146;s financial statements for these awards includes
    the probability assumption that 100% of the performance options
    issued will vest by December&#160;31, 2012.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-33
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The range of exercise prices was $4.13 to $46.51 and the
    weighted average remaining contractual life was 8.3&#160;years
    for stock options outstanding as of December&#160;31, 2007. The
    weighted average contractual life of stock options that were
    vested and unexercised at December&#160;31, 2007 was
    5.4&#160;years. The aggregate intrinsic value of these options
    was $12.1&#160;million. If these options were exercised, the
    Company would receive an additional $13.1&#160;million of
    capital.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    the stock option grants outstanding at December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

    with a weighted average remaining life of 4.5&#160;years.

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The range of exercise prices was $26.10 to $33.15 and the
    weighted average remaining contractual life was 9.8&#160;years
    for SARs outstanding as of December&#160;31, 2007. There were no
    SARs vested and unexercised.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table presents the exercise prices for the SARs
    outstanding at December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <TD width="68%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->

</TR>
<!-- Table Width Row END -->
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">

</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2007, total unrecognized compensation
    costs related to unvested stock options was $11.8&#160;million
    with a weighted average remaining life of 5&#160;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Stock Option and
    SARs Valuation</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006 and 2007, the Company granted stock options to a
    portion of its employees and to all of its non-employee
    directors. All stock option grants are approved by the
    Company&#146;s Board of Directors on the grant date or a
    specifically designated future date. These stock options are
    exercisable at the price equal to the closing price of the
    Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To derive the estimated fair value of these stock options, the
    Company used the Cox-Ross-Rubenstein binomial method of valuing
    options. The Company adopted this formula in the second quarter
    of 2004. Previously the Black-Scholes method was used. The
    Cox-Ross-Rubenstein formula is similar to the Black-Scholes
    method because it uses similar inputs of expected term, expected
    volatility, interest rate and dividend yield.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Beginning in 2006, the Company derived expected term by using
    the calculation prescribed in the SEC&#146;s Staff Accounting
    Bulletin&#160;No.&#160;107 &#147;Share Based Payment&#148;
    (&#147;SAB&#160;107&#148;). This calculation arrives at expected
    term using the vesting schedule and the contractual term of the
    stock options. Late in 2007, the Company engaged a consultant to
    perform an analysis and determine expected lives based on actual
    historical exercise behavior. The results of this analysis were
    used for all valuations after its completion.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Beginning in 2006, the Company changed its method for
    determining expected volatility. Expected volatility is
    calculated by combining the historical volatility on the
    Company&#146;s exchange traded common stock and the implied
    volatility on the exchange traded stock options that are derived
    from the value of the Company&#146;s exchange traded common
    stock. In previous years, the Company used the expected
    volatility computed solely from an index of strategic peers and
    their common stock volatility. The Company changed its method
    for calculating expected volatility because of the shortening of
    the expected term of the options granted in 2006 and the length
    of time the Company&#146;s stock has been traded on a publicly
    accessible exchange, the latter validating reliance on the
    Company&#146;s own common stock historical volatility. In 2007,
    the Company determined that it was appropriate to use historical
    volatility from its inception as a publicly traded company.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The interest rate and dividend yield calculations remain
    unchanged from prior years. The interest rate is the
    U.S.&#160;Treasury yield over the expected term of the stock
    options. The dividend yield is calculated by annualizing the
    Company&#146;s most recent dividend paid and dividing by the
    Company&#146;s market capitalization.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-35
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">PRIVATEBANCORP,
    INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES&#151;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Stock options and SARs with performance conditions are valued
    using the same method as the Company&#146;s previously issued
    &#147;plain vanilla&#148; options. Performance conditions are
    not included as part of the valuation process. Due to the number
    of vesting possibilities based on when a performance condition
    is attained, the performance options have been valued in
    multiple tranches. Stock options with performance conditions
    were valued on the grant date. SARs were valued on
    December&#160;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In determining the fair value of each option grant, the Company
    used the following assumptions:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->

    <TD width="26%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Restricted Stock
    and RSUs</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Restricted shares issued under the Incentive Compensation Plan
    carry voting and dividend rights. Sale of the shares is
    restricted prior to vesting. Subject to continued employment,
    vesting occurs five years from the date of grant. Upon adoption
    of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R), the Company records compensation
    expense on a straight-line basis over the vesting period based
    on the fair market value on the grant date.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Restricted shares issued under the Transformation Plan carry
    voting rights, RSUs do not. Dividends are accrued and paid out
    upon vesting of the shares and RSUs. Sale of the shares is
    restricted prior to vesting. Vesting occurs upon achievement of
    a 20% compounded annual growth rate in the Company&#146;s stock
    price over a five-year period ending December&#160;31, 2012. The
    baseline stock price is $27.91. In each year, the Company&#146;s
    stock must have a closing price greater than 20% of the prior
    year stock price growth hurdle for 20 consecutive trading days.
    In any year in which the target is missed, that award can be
    earned in a succeeding year by achieving that year&#146;s
    target. If none of these targets are achieved, 25% of the
    restricted shares originally issued will vest if the recipient
    is still employed by the Company on December&#160;31, 2012. In
    no circumstance will more than 100% of the originally issued
    restricted shares or RSUs vest.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since vesting is mostly dependent on stock price targets, the
    Transformation restricted shares and RSUs contain a market
    condition as defined by SFAS&#160;123R. This market condition is
    included in the valuation calculation of the awards. The award
    is divided into separately valued tranches. The Company records
    compensation expense on a straight-line basis for each tranche
    over the anticipated time it will take for the award to vest.
    This period of time is called the derived service period as
    defined by SFAS&#160;123R.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Included in salaries and employee benefits in the consolidated
    statements of income is compensation expense for restricted
    shares and RSUs, net of forfeits of $3.5&#160;million in 2007,
    $2.3&#160;million in 2006, and $1.9&#160;million in 2005. The
    total recognized tax benefit related to this compensation
    expense was $1.2&#160;million in 2007, $819,000 in 2006 and
    $681,000 in 2005. The total fair value of restricted shares
    vested was $188,000 in 2007, $2.6&#160;million in 2006, and
    $2.5&#160;million in 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-36
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

    splits and changes during the years then ended:
</DIV>

    <B>Weighted<BR>

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
